title: The manuscripts of His Grace the Duke of Portland, preserved at Welbeck abbey ...
snippet: At Wentbridge, seven miles from Doncaster, we parted from the Great York Road and kept to the left over the bridge of three arches for Pontefract, through a large field of furze, where there is good soil, but ill husbanded ; kept much to the left, and came through a little village called Carlton, to Mr. Watson's at the " Star" Inn, at Pomfret (Pontefract) from Doncaster in three hours and fifty minutes, computed ten miles.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: In the summer of 1888, another gentleman and I started fromBangor for the Giant's Causeway, leaving Bangor about eight o'clocka.m., and Belfast about half-past nine, from the York Road station of theNorthern Counties Railway. The Giant's Causeway is about seventyfour and a-half miles from Belfast, and you pass on your journey someof the finest parts of the northern counties, but I shall only mention afew places as we go along.

title: The manuscripts of His Grace the Duke of Portland, preserved at Welbeck abbey ...
snippet: l^leven miles from Welbeck we came to Rossington m four hours. At Rossington Bridge, which consists of two arches, on one of which is a date 1G33, we strike into the Great York Road. A little further we leave Tanclay (Cantley?) church to the right, and the course for the Doncaster horseraces, where there is a machine, with a new plantation of trees round it, which I suppose is the weighing post, but looks much moi'e like a gallows.
